statement:
If $\{ X_t, t \in T \}$ is a stationary process with mean $\mu$ and
autocovariance function $\gamma(\cdotp)$, then as $n \to  \infty$ we
have the following:

-   $\var[\bar X_n]= E[ (\bar X_n - \mu)^2 ] \to 0$ if $\gamma(n) \to 0$

-   $nE[ (\bar X_n - \mu)^2] \to \sum_{h=-\infty}^{\infty}\gamma(h)$ if
    $\sum_{h=-\infty}^{\infty}|\gamma(h)|<\infty$ where
    $$\bar X_n=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=1}^{n} X_k$$ is the sample mean which
    is a natural unbiased estimator of the mean $\mu$ of the stationary
    process $\{ X_t\}$.

[6]{} Peter J. Brockwell G., Richard A. Davis , [*Time Series
$\colon$Theory and Methods*]{}.
names: mean square convergence of the sample mean of a stationary process
